comment._content: Could this be the Pamir? Here's a photo for comparison: upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/80/Pamir_(ship,_1905)_-_SLV_H91.250-567.jpg Most of the photos I've seen have the forecastle painted white, I can't make it out from this photo but here's one photo with it painted black: www.kolumbus.fi/jamikko/Pamir%20SB.jpg I hope this helps, Phill

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/35317829@N06] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/seaveyfamily] Hi all, I can now confirm that this vessel does not depict PAMIR, it depicts the MOSHULU, which was built in 1904 originally as KURT. We have two other photographs of MOSHULU which we will upload soon so stay tuned. :)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 35317829@N06
comment._content: I look forward to it, it's great we can positively identify this ship! :)

comment.author: 29381659@N07
comment._content: Instant fave! I live in Philadelphia, where Moshulu now resides and is a pretty good restaurant. It's one of my favorite summer twilight / night photo subjects. Another ship of the same class is Peking (and had a similar working life), which is docked in NYC at the South Street Seaport. I searched ANMM Flickr photos for Peking, but didn't see anything. Moshulu supposedly won the "The Last Grain Race" in 1939 or so, as explained in a fascinating descriptive book by Eric Newby. All competing boats were on related trade routes, how long to get from Australia back to England. I think Moshulu in 1939 was 91 days or so. These boats (& sailors) were tough - see the DVD: www.amazon.com/Around-Cape-Horn-Johnson-Sailing/dp/B000W8...
